These units are connected via a [[planetary gear]] and three electrically controlled hydraulic [[clutch]]es to provide power output for propulsion in any of four programmed operating modes: # Single motor electric – The primary motor runs solely on battery power, maximum propulsion power is 111 kW. # Dual motor electric – At higher vehicle speeds the secondary motor engages over the planetary gear such that it reduces the speed of the primary motor. This facilitates higher efficiency and better mileage for the combined system, without increasing the maximum power. # Single motor extended – The battery reaches its minimum charge, which triggers the combustion engine. The engine drives the secondary motor as a generator, via the charging electronics, to keep the minimum battery charge level. The primary motor can still provide its 111 kW for short acceleration, albeit not sustained. # Dual motor extended – The electric motors are used again in dual configuration with increased efficiency at higher speeds. Additionally the gasoline engine contributes propulsion power via the planetary gear. While power is drained from the battery the amount is less than in mode 2 for the same propulsion power, thus extending the range. The drivetrain permits the Volt to operate as a pure [[battery electric vehicle]] until its battery capacity has been depleted to a defined level, at which time it commences to operate as a [[Types of hybrid vehicle#Series hybrid|series hybrid]] design where the gasoline engine drives the generator, which keeps the battery at minimum level charge and provides power to the electric motors. The full charge of the battery is replenished only by loading it on the [[electrical grid]].
While in this series mode at higher speeds and loads, (typically above {{Convert|30|mph}} at light to moderate loads) the gasoline engine can engage mechanically to the output from the transmission and assist both electric motors in driving the wheels, in which case the Volt operates as a [[Series-parallel hybrid|power-split or series-parallel hybrid]]. After its all-electric range has been depleted, at speeds between {{Convert|30|to|70|mph}}, the Volt is programmed to select the most efficient drive mode, which improves performance and boosts high-speed efficiency by 10 to 15 percent.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/10/chevy-volt-delivers-novel-two-motor-four-mode-extended-range-electric-drive-system-seamless-driver-e.html#more|title=Chevy Volt Delivers Novel Two-Motor, Four-Mode Extended Range Electric Drive System; Seamless Driver Experience Plus Efficiency|work=Green Car Congress|date=2010-10-20|accessdate=2010-10-21}} While operating modes are switched automatically the Volt allows the driver to choose from three drive modes: normal, sport and mountain. The mountain mode, which is expected to be required only under unusual power demand conditions, increases minimum battery [[state of charge]] (SOC) to around 45%, thus maintaining performance on steep and long grades. The driver hears more engine noise due to the higher rate of power generation required to maintain this mode. The sport mode causes the engine to rev higher, and the response to the throttle pedal is quicker.{{cite news|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/reviews/hybrid-electric/volt-reliability-report-test|title=900 Miles Reliability Report in the Chevy Volt|work=[[Popular Mechanics]]|date=2010-10-10|accessdate=2010-10-11}} The Ampera has an additional option, the "City Mode" or "battery hold", allowing the driver to save the energy currently stored in the battery for use when traveling in urban areas or restricted zones. The 2013 model year Volt includes a "Hold" option to provide the same choice. ==== Battery ==== {{See also|Electric vehicle battery}} The 2011 Volt's [[lithium-ion battery]] (Li-ion) battery pack weighs {{convert|435|lb|kg|abbr=on}} and "consists of 288 individual cells arranged into nine modules. Plastic frames hold pairs of lithium-ion cells that sandwich an aluminum [[cooling fin]]. The design and construction of that aluminum plate was critical to ensuring an even temperature distribution with no hot or cool spots across the flat, rectangular cell. The battery pack has its own cooling circuit that is similar to, but independent from, the engine cooling system."{{cite press release |url=http://media.gm.com/media/us/en/gm/news.detail.print.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2011/Feb/0214_battery.html |title=Cooling Fins Help Keep Chevrolet Volt Battery at Ideal Temperature |publisher=General Motors |location=US |work=GM Volt Media Portal |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-04-28}} [[File:Chevrolet Volt charging WAS 2011 833.jpg|thumb|left|Inlet for the electrical charger in the left side of the Chevrolet Volt with the manufacturer's provided charging cord]] For the 2011/2012 model years, the battery pack stores {{kWh|16}} of energy but it is controlled or buffered via the energy management system to use only {{kWh|10.3}} of this capacity to maximize the life of the pack. For this reason the battery pack never fully charges or depletes, as the software only allows the battery to operate within a [[state of charge]] (SOC) window of 65%, after which the engine kicks in and maintains the charge near the lower level. The minimum SOC varies depending on operating conditions. When the car needs more power, such as in mountain mode, the lower limit of the SOC rises to 45% to ensure enough power is available. The battery capacity was increased to {{kWh|16.5}} for the 2013 [[model year]], the SOC window was increased to use {{kWh|10.8}} of the total battery energy, and the buffer to ensure battery life is not reduced. These changes increases the Volt's [[all-electric range]], but charging takes slightly longer. GM achieved the improved battery performance and durability through minor changes to the material composition of the battery cell chemistry.{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1076766_2013-chevy-volt-gets-38-mile-electric-range-higher-98-mpge-rating|title=2013 Chevy Volt Gets 38-Mile Electric Range, Higher 98-MPGe Rating |last=Voelcker |first=John |website=Green Car Reports |date=2012-06-07 |accessdate=2012-06-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/06/2013volt-20120607.html |title=GM tweaks battery materials, pack size, SOC window to increase 2013 Chevrolet Volt EV range to 38 miles |author= |website=Green Car Congress |date=2012-06-07|accessdate=2012-06-09}} Despite containing near identical energy (+/- {{kWh|0.5}}), the Volt's battery pack is over 70% lighter than the [[EV1]]'s original {{convert|1310|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, {{kWh|16.5}} AC Delco [[lead-acid battery]] pack, mainly because the Volt uses higher [[specific energy]] Li-ion batteries. Li-ion batteries are expected to become less expensive as [[economy of scale|economies of scale]] take effect.{{cite journal |url=http://avt.inel.gov/pdf/fsev/eva/ev1_eva.pdf |title=EVAmerica Baseline Performance Testing, 1999 General Motors EV1 with NiMH Batteries |publisher=[[US Department of Energy]] (DOE), [[Idaho National Laboratory]] (INL), Advanced Vehicle Testing Activity (AVTA) |date=2002-07-30 |accessdate=2009-10-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webharvest.gov/peth04/20041017150240/http://avt.inel.gov/pdf/fsev/eva/ev1_eva.pdf |archivedate=2004-10-17 |df= }}{{cite journal |url=http://avt.inel.gov/pdf/fsev/eva/ev1_eva.pdf |title=EVAmerica Baseline Performance Testing, 1997 General Motors EV1 with PbA Batteries |publisher=[[US Department of Energy]] (DOE), [[Idaho National Laboratory]] (INL), Advanced Vehicle Testing Activity (AVTA) |date=2002-08-02 |accessdate=2009-10-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webharvest.gov/peth04/20041017150240/http://avt.inel.gov/pdf/fsev/eva/ev1_eva.pdf |archivedate=2004-10-17 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.evchargernews.com/CD-A/gm_ev1_web_site/specs/specs_specs_top.htm |title=EV1 – specs |date=2001-04-17 |accessdate=2009-10-09}} Because batteries are sensitive to temperature changes, the Volt has a thermal management system to monitor and maintain the battery cell temperature for optimum performance and durability. The Volt's battery pack provides reliable operation, when plugged in, at cell temperatures as low as {{Convert|-13|F|C|abbr=on}} and as high as {{Convert|122|F|C|abbr=on}}.{{cite book |url=http://www.chevrolet.com/content/dam/Chevrolet/northamerica/usa/nscwebsite/en/Home/Ownership/Manuals%20and%20Videos/02_pdf/2k14volt2ndPrint.pdf |title=2014 Chevrolet VOLT Owner Manual |publisher=Chevrolet |location=US |accessdate=2014-07-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140120184111/http://www.chevrolet.com/content/dam/Chevrolet/northamerica/usa/nscwebsite/en/Home/Ownership/Manuals%20and%20Videos/02_pdf/2k14volt2ndPrint.pdf |archive-date=2014-01-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The Volt features a battery pack that can be both warmed or cooled. In cold weather, the car electrically heats the battery coolant during charging or operation to provide full power capability. In hot weather, the car can use its air conditioner to cool the battery coolant to prevent over-temperature damage.{{cite web|url=http://gm-volt.com/2010/12/09/the-chevrolet-volt-coolingheating-systems-explained/|title=The Chevrolet Volt Cooling/Heating Systems Explained|publisher=GM-Volt.com|date=2010-12-10|accessdate=2014-07-26}} General Motors guarantees the Volt's battery for eight years or {{convert|100,000|mi|km}}, and cover all 161 battery components.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/15/business/15auto.html?_r=1&ref=automobiles|title=G.M. to Offer 8-Year Guarantee for New Electric Car’s Battery |last=Zeller |first=Tom, Jr.|newspaper=The New York Times |date=2010-07-14 |accessdate=2010-07-15}} GM estimates that Volt batteries will degrade by 10 to 30% after 8 years or 100,000 miles.{{cite web |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-20022049-54.html |title=GM envisions refreshing EV batteries |work=CNET News Green Tech |last=LaMonica |first=Martin |date=2010-11-08 |accessdate=2011-04-28}} GM has applied for a patent that may allow technicians to quickly and cheaply recover some of the performance of degraded battery packs.{{cite web|url=http://gm-volt.com/2010/11/08/gm-applies-for-patent-for-lithium-ion-battery-cell-refurbishing-system|title=GM Applies for Patent for Lithium-ion Battery Cell Refurbishing System|work=GM-Volt.com|date=2010-11-08|accessdate=2012-05-16}} The Volt’s battery management system runs more than 500 diagnostics at 10 times per second, allowing it to keep track of the Volt’s battery pack in real-time, 85% of which ensure the battery pack is operating safely and 15% monitor battery performance and life.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/07/volt-20100714.html|title=Chevrolet Volt Battery Pack Carries Standard Eight-Year, 100,000-Mile Warranty|work=Green Car Congress|date=2010-07-14|accessdate=2011-05-23}} The Volt uses a plug specification published in 2009, [[SAE J1772|SAE J1772-2009]], that is considered a standard for electric cars in North America.{{cite web |title=Plug Standard Needed For Electric Car-Charging Cord Interface: SAE J1772|date=2009-03-30|url=http://gm-volt.com/2009/04/16/plug-standard-needed-for-electric-car-charging-cord-interface-sae-j1772/#comment-107648|accessdate=2009-04-06}} Depending on in-car settings a full charge takes from approximately 10 hours (12A setting) to as much as 14 hours (8A setting) from a standard North American 120 [[Volt|V]], 15 [[Ampere|A]] outlet and about 4 hours from a 240 V AC source and suitable 240 V [[EVSE]]. The Volt comes with a {{Convert|20|ft|m|abbr=on}} charging cord suitable for the standard household power outlet in its country of sale. If plugged in, recharging can be controlled remotely through a smartphone application. ==== Others ==== To save energy, the Volt sometimes heats the seats instead of blowing heated air through [[HVAC]] system, as heating the vehicle's cabin draws significant power, and can even exceed what is needed to move the vehicle on occasions.http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2011-chevrolet-volt-full-test-road-test 2011 Chevrolet Volt Full Test from the Car and Driver (Dec 2010) A power-saving stereo system uses amplifiers that switch on and off rapidly to save power. It uses 50 percent less energy. The system is also lighter because the use of high grade [[neodymium magnet]]s. === Performance === The Volt has a top speed of {{convert|100|mph|abbr=on}}. According to [[Edmunds.com]] road tests, the Volt's [[0 to 60 mph]] {{nowrap|(0–97 km/h)}} acceleration time is 9.2 seconds running on electric-only mode, and 9.0 seconds with the gasoline engine assisting propulsion.{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/chevrolet/volt/2011/road-test-specs.html|title=2011 Chevrolet Volt Road Test Specs|work=Edmunds.com|accessdate=2011-06-05}} [[Motor Trend]] reports the Volt's quarter mile (402 m) time is 16.9 sec @ {{Convert|84.3|mph|abbr=on}},{{cite news|url=http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/oneyear/1106_2011_chevrolet_volt_arrival/index.html|title=Arrival: 2011 Chevrolet Volt|author=Frank Markus|work=[[Motor Trend]]|date=2011-04-13|accessdate=2011-05-08}} ''Over {{convert|2360|mi|km}}'' driven while Edmunds reports a quarter mile (402 m) time of 16.8 sec @ {{Convert|81.5|mph|abbr=on}} in electric-only operation, and 16.6 sec @ {{Convert|85.5|mph|abbr=on}} with the gasoline engine assisting. Motor Trend reports a {{Convert|60|to|0|mph|abbr=on}} braking distance of {{Convert|112|ft|m|abbr=on}} and Edmunds.com of {{Convert|124|ft|m|abbr=on}}. ==== Range ==== [[File:2013 Chevrolet Volt EPA sticker.png|thumb| [[Monroney label]] showing EPA's fuel economy and environmental comparison label for the 2013 Chevrolet Volt]] According to General Motors the Volt's [[all-electric range]] with fully charged batteries varies from {{convert|25|to|50|mi}} depending on terrain, driving technique, and temperature.{{cite web|url=http://www.chevroletvoltage.com/index.php/volt-blog/18-volt/2240-2011-chevrolet-volt-receives-new-fuel-economy-label-from-epa.html|title=2011 Chevrolet Volt Receives New Fuel Economy Label From EPA | Volt |work=Chevroletvoltage.com |date=2010-11-24|accessdate=2011-06-02}} The 2013 model year Volt increased its EPA's rated all-electric range to {{Convert|38|mi}}. The 2014 and 2015 Volt have the same EPA ratings.{{cite web|url=https://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=32655&id=33900&id=35246|title=2013 and 2014 and 2015 Chevrolet Volt|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2015-06-09|accessdate=2015-06-09}} The Opel Ampera official all-electric range under the EU-approved [[World Forum for Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations#Environmental compatibility|UN ECE R101]] standard for plug-in hybrids is {{convert|83|km|mi|abbr=on}}. {{cite journal|title=Ein Auto mit eigenem Kraftwerk |first=Klaus |last=Brieter |journal=[[ADAC|ADAC Motorwelt]] |year=2012 |issue=1 |language=German |pages=26–30}} ==== Fuel economy ==== ;United States [[File:2012 Chevrolet Volt EPA window sticker 0483.jpg|thumb|2012 Volt EPA/DOT Window sticker showed potential fuel cost saving.]] The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) officially rated the 2011 model year Volt's combined city/highway [[fuel economy in automobiles|fuel economy]] in [[all-electric mode]] at 93 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPG-e) (2.5 L gasoline equivalent/100 km; 112 mpg-imp gasoline equivalent) and 94 MPG-e for the 2012 model year. For the 2012 model year, EPA revised the Volt's fuel economy ratings, increasing the combined city/highway rating in all-electric mode from 93 MPG-e to 94 MPG-e, and the highway rating was increased from 90 MPG-e to 93 MPG-e.{{cite web |url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/phevsbs.shtml |title=2011–12 Chevrolet Volt|author= |website=Fueleconomy.gov |date=2011-11-07 |accessdate=2011-11-07}} As a result of its improved battery pack, the 2013 model year EPA rating climbed to a combined city/highway fuel economy of 98 miles per gallon gasoline equivalent (2.4 L gasoline equivalent/100 km; 118 mpg-imp gasoline equivalent). ;Europe The Opel Ampera official equivalent fuel consumption under the EU-approved UN ECE R101 standard for plug-in hybrids is {{convert|1.2|L/100 km|mpgus mpgimp|abbr=on|1}} (83.3 km/L).{{cite web |last=Hedevang |first=Kurt |url=http://fpn.dk/motor/bil/article2560207.ece |title=Opel Ampera below 600,000 DKK |language=Danish |publisher=Consumer Online |date=2011-09-28 |accessdate=2011-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006071224/http://fpn.dk/motor/bil/article2560207.ece |archivedate=2011-10-06 |df= }} However, a leading Opel engineer prefers saying 169 Wh/km (16.9 kWh/100 km) while battery-powered, and then 20 km/L (5 L/100 km) petrol-powered. The ECE R101 standard weights [[charge-depleting]] mode as 76% and gasoline-only driving as 24%.{{cite web |last=Arent |first=Torben |url=http://www.fdm.dk/nyheder/opels-miljoebil-klar-83-kml |publisher=United Car Owners |title=Opels miljøbil klar: 83 km/l |language=Danish |date=2011-09-27 |accessdate=2011-10-18}} ''Title translation: Opel's eco-car ready: 83 km/L'' ===Operating cost and payback period=== According to ''[[Consumer Reports]]'' in December 2011, the Chevrolet Volt fuel cost in electric mode was 3.8[[Cent (currency)|¢]]/mile. {{cite news |url=http://news.consumerreports.org/cars/2011/12/leaf-volt-tests-show-electric-cars-cost-less-per-mile-to-operate.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108013333/http://news.consumerreports.org/cars/2011/12/leaf-volt-tests-show-electric-cars-cost-less-per-mile-to-operate.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-01-08 |title=Leaf, Volt Tests Show Electric Cars Cost Less per Mile To Operate |last=Evarts |first=Eric |work=Consumer Reports |date=2011-12-08 |accessdate=2011-12-09 }} According to [[Edmunds.com]], the price premium paid for the Volt in 2012, after discounting the {{USD|7,500}} [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#New plug-in electric vehicles|U.S. federal tax credit]], takes a long time for consumers to recover in fuel savings, often longer than the normal ownership time period. {{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/industry-center/analysis/will-higher-gas-prices-boost-hybrid-ev-sales.html|title=Will Higher Gas Prices Boost Hybrid, EV Sales? |last=Krebs |first=Michelle |website=Edmunds.com|date=2012-02-28|accessdate=2012-02-29}} ===Tailpipe emissions=== {{Main|Plug-in hybrid#Greenhouse gas emissions|l1=Greenhouse gas emissions in plug-in hybrids|Plug-in electric vehicle#Air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions|l2=Air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions in plug-in electric vehicles}} === Safety === {{Euro NCAP |align=right |year=2011 |overall_stars=5 |description=Chevrolet Volt |reference_code=451 |adult_points=30 |adult_percent=85 |child_points=38 |child_percent=78 |pedestrian_points=15 |pedestrian_percent=41 |safety_points=6 |safety_percent=86 }} The Volt received a five-star overall crash safety rating from the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA), the highest-possible score. This rating was obtained with NHTSA's New Car Assessment Program for 2011 [[model year]] vehicles.{{cite web |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/06/03/chevy-volt-earns-five-star-nhtsa-crash-rating-w-videos |title=Chevy Volt earns five-star NHTSA crash rating |work=AutoblogGreen |last=Blanco |first=Sebastien |date=2011-06-03 |accessdate=2011-06-03}} ;Accident and rescue handling In August 2010, General Motors began a training program for first responders when performing rescue duties involving the Chevrolet Volt. .{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/08/gmfr-20100827.html|title= General Motors Kicks Off National Electric Vehicle Training Tour For First Responders|work=Green Car Congress|date=2010-08-27|accessdate=2011-11-11}} ;Warning sounds Due to significant noise reduction typical of vehicles traveling in [[all-electric mode]] at low speeds, the Volt is fitted with a manually activated [[Electric vehicle warning sounds|electronic warning sound system]] called ''Pedestrian-Friendly Alert System'' for use when the car is operating at low speeds to alert pedestrians to the car's presence.{{cite web |last=Motavalli |first=Jim |date=2010-06-01 |title=Electric Car Warning Sounds: Don’t Expect Ring Tones |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/01/electric-car-warning-sounds-dont-expect-ringtones/ |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |at=Wheels |accessdate=2010-06-02}} == Second generation (2016-present)== {{main|Chevrolet Volt (second generation)}} [[File:2016 Chevrolet Volt NAIAS 2015 trimmed.jpg|thumb|The [[Chevrolet Volt (second generation)|second generation Chevrolet Volt]] was unveiled at the 2015 [[North American International Auto Show]].]] The second generation Chevrolet Volt was officially unveiled at the January 2015 [[North American International Auto Show]].{{cite news|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2015/01/next-gen-chevy-volt-erev-is-more-efficient-with-50-mile-electric-range.html|title=Next-gen Chevy Volt EREV is more efficient, with 50-mile electric range|author=Mike Millikin |work=Green Car Congress |date=2015-01-12|accessdate=2015-01-12}} Retail deliveries began in the United States and Canada in October 2015 as a 2016 [[model year]], with 1,324 units delivered in the U.S. that month.{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/2016-volts-account-for-1324-sales-out-of-2035-october-deliveries/|title=2016 Volts Account For 1,324 Sales Out Of 2,035 October Deliveries|author=Jeff Cobb|work=HybridCars.com|date=2015-11-03|accessdate=2015-11-03}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1100803_plug-in-electric-car-sales-in-canada-october-2015-the-wallet-ballot|title=Plug-in Electric Car Sales in Canada, October 2015: The Wallet Ballot|first=Matthew |last=Klippenstein |publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2015-11-06|accessdate=2015-11-07}} Availability in the American market was limited to California and the other 10 states that follow [[California Air Resources Board#California zero-emissions vehicle|California’s zero emission vehicle]] regulations. GM scheduled the second generation as a 2017 model year to be released in the 39 remaining states by early 2016. Manufacturing of the 2017 MY Volt began in February 2016, and the first units arrived at dealerships at the end of February 2016. The 2017 model complies with stricter Tier 3 emissions requirements and was available nationwide.{{cite web| url=http://insideevs.com/2017-chevrolet-volt-arrives-dealerships-deals-announced/ |title=2017 Chevrolet Volt Arrives At Dealerships, Deals Announced |first=Steven |last=Loveday |publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2016-02-28|accessdate=2016-02-28}} The second generation Volt has an upgraded powertrain with a 1.5-liter engine that uses regular gasoline; the 18.4 [[kWh]] battery pack has new chemistry that stores 20% more electrical energy and uses fewer cells, 192 compared with 288 on the 2014 Volt; it uses a new power controller that is integrated with the motor housing; the electric motors weigh {{Convert|100|lb|abbr=on}} less and use smaller amounts of [[Rare earth element|rare earth metals]]. GM engineers explained that the second generation Volt was developed using extensive input from Volt owners.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/29/automobiles/chevrolet-unveils-new-volt-powertrain.html?|title=New Volt Will Have Improved Powertrain and Longer Range|author=Lindsay Brooke|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2014-10-28|accessdate=2014-11-15}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2014/10/28/chevrolet-volt-gm-general-motors-ceo-mary-barra/18053171/ |title= GM CEO: 2016 Volt gets U.S. drivetrain, Detroit debut|author1=Mark Phelan |author2=Greg Gardner |work= [[USA Today]] |date= 2014-11-01 |accessdate= 2014-10-28}} [[File:Chevrolet Volt WAS 2017 1731.jpg|thumb|left|2017 model year Chevrolet Volt]] These improvements allow the 2016 Volt to deliver better EPA ratings than the first generation model. The all-electric range was officially rated at {{Convert|53|mi|abbr=on}}, up from {{Convert|38|mi|abbr=on}} attained by the 2015 Volt. The gains in efficiency allow the second generation Volt to improve its combined fuel economy in gasoline-only ([[charge-sustaining]]) mode to {{Convert|42|mpgUS|abbr=on}}, up from {{Convert|37|mpgUS|abbr=on}} for the previous model. The official second generation Volt's rating for combined city/highway fuel economy in [[all-electric mode]] is 106 [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (MPG-e; 2.2Le/100Km), up from 98 MPG-e (2.4Le/Km) for the 2015 first generation model.{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/2016-chevrolet-volt-rated-for-53-miles-electric-range/|title=2016 Chevrolet Volt Rated For 53 Miles Electric Range|author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com|date=2015-08-04|accessdate=2015-08-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=36863&id=35246|title=Compare Side-by-Side - 2016/2015 Chevrolet Volt|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2015-09-01|accessdate=2015-09-02}} The combined gasoline-electricity fuel economy rating of the 2016 model year Volt is {{Convert|77|mpgus|abbr=on}} [[miles per gallon gasoline equivalent|equivalent]], 82 MPG-e (2.9Le/Km) in city driving and 72 MPG-e (3.3Le/Km) in highway.{{cite web|url=http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/topten.jsp|title=Fueleconomy.gov's Top Fuel Sippers (EPA Ratings, All Years) |publisher=fueleconomy.gov|author=[[U. S. Environmental Protection Agency]] and [[U.S. Department of Energy]]|date=2015-12-04|accessdate=2015-12-05}} ''Excludes all-electric vehicles. Click on the tab "Top Fuel Sippers (EPA Ratings, All Years)" - The 2013-2014 Chevrolet Volt has a combined fuel economy of 62 MPGe (3.8Le/Km), while 2016 Volt has a combined fuel economy of 77 MPGe (3Le/Km). The BMW i3 REx has a combined fuel economy of 88 MPGe (2.7Le/Km)'' Both the all-electric range and fuel economy ratings are the same for the 2017 model year Volt.{{cite web|url= http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=37309&id=36863 |title=Compare Side-by-Side - 2017/2016 Chevrolet Volt|publisher=Fueleconomy.gov|author=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and U.S. Department of Energy|date=2016-03-18 |accessdate=2016-03-20}} [[File:Chevrolet Volt WAS 2017 1516.jpg|thumb|Second generation [[GM Voltec powertrain|Voltec]] 1.5L gasoline-powered engine (left) and power inverter on top of the traction electric motor (right).]] In April 2013, CEO [[Daniel Akerson]] announced that GM expects the second generation Volt to be priced on the order of {{USD|7,000}} to {{USD|10,000}} lower than the 2013 model year with the same features.{{cite web |url=http://insideevs.com/gm-ceo-chevrolet-volt-price-to-drop-by-7000-to-10000-for-next-gen/ |title=GM CEO: Chevrolet Volt Price To Drop By $7,000 to $10,000 For Next Gen |last=Cole |first=Jay |work=InsideEVs.com |date=2013-04-30 |accessdate=2013-05-01}} The 2016 Volt pricing started at {{USD|33,170}} before any [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#United States|government incentives]], plus {{USD|825}} for destination. The starting price was {{USD|1,175}} lower than the 2015 Volt.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1098130_2016-chevrolet-volt-priced-from-33995-or-1195-lower-than-2015-volt|title=2016 Chevrolet Volt Priced From $33,995, Or $1,175 Lower Than 2015 Volt|author=John Voelcker|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2015-05-03|accessdate=2015-06-14}} In California, order books for the second generation Volt were opened on May 28, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoblog.com/2015/05/27/2016-chevy-volt-orders-start-tomorrow/|title=Chevy Volt orders start tomorrow|author=Chris Bruce|publisher=Autoblog.com|date=2015-05-27|accessdate=2015-06-14}} In July 2014, Opel announced that due to the slowdown in sales, they would discontinue the Ampera after the launch of the second generation Volt—and that between 2014 and 2018, Opel planned to introduce a successor electric vehicle in Europe. General Motors announced in February 2016 that the all-electric [[Opel Ampera-e]] hatchback would go into production in 2017. This is the European version of the [[Chevrolet Bolt EV]].{{cite news|url= http://fortune.com/2016/02/11/gm-chevy-bolt-opel-ampera-e/| title=GM Unveils an All-Electric Car for Europe |first=Kirsten |last=Korosec |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2016-02-11 |accessdate=2016-02-12}}{{cite news | url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/02/12/opel-ampera-e-chevy-bolt-europe/#slide-3796659 |title= Opel Ampera-e brings a Bolt of EV driving to Europe |first= Chris |last= Bruce |work=Autoblog.com |date=2016-02-12 |accessdate=2016-02-12}} In April 2015, General Motors confirmed that it would not build the second generation Volt in [[right-hand-drive]] configuration. '''(2)''' Price in the Eurozone countries includes [[VAT]]. |} === North America === Assembly of the Volt was assigned to [[Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly]] plant following the conclusion of the 2007 [[United Auto Workers|UAW-GM]] [[2007 General Motors strike|contract talks]].{{cite news |last=Terlep |first=Sharon |last2=Aguilar |first2=Louis |title=Detroit to build GM's car of future |date=2007-09-29 |work=Detroit News |url=http://www.detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070929/AUTO01/709290383/1148}} For initial production the gasoline engine is being imported from the [[Opel]] engine plant in [[Aspern]], [[Austria]].{{cite news |first=Ron |last=Fonger |title=Chevy Volt's first range-extending engines will come from Austria, not Flint |url=http://www.mlive.com/naias/index.ssf/2009/01/volts_first_rangeextending_eng.html |work=MLive |publisher=MLive Media Group |date=2009-01-13|accessdate=2009-01-15}} In November 2010, General Motors began investing {{USD|138.3}} million at its engine operations plant in [[Flint, Michigan]] to support increased production of the [[Ecotec]] 1.4 L engine that is used in the [[Chevrolet Cruze]], the upcoming 2012 [[Chevrolet Sonic]], and the variant used in the Chevrolet Volt. The Flint plant was expected to start production of 400 engines a day in early 2011, ramp up daily production to 800 engines in late 2011, and to increase its capacity to 1,200 a day by late 2012.{{cite web|author= |date=2010-11-24 |title=GM to Invest $163 Million, Retain 184 Jobs in Three Plants |url=http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/news/news_detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/Nov/1124_pt_flint |deadurl=yes |website=GM News |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20101127185020/http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/news/news_detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/Nov/1124_pt_flint |archivedate=2010-11-27 |accessdate=2011-05-19 |df= }} In May 2011, General Motors decided to invest an additional {{USD|84 million}} at the Flint plant to further increase 1.4 L engine production capacity.{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/05/gm-investing-109m-in-mich-plants-to-support-14l-ecotec-engines-general-motors-will-invest-109-million-in-its-operations.html |title=GM investing $109M in Mich plants to support 1.4L Ecotec engines |work=Green Car Congress |date=2011-05-13 |accessdate=2011-05-19}} In 2010, General Motors planned an initial production for calendar year 2011 of 10,000 Volts and 45,000 units for 2012, up from the 30,000 units initially announced.{{cite web|url=http://blog.caranddriver.com/chevrolet-increases-projected-2012-volt-production-capacity-by-50-percent/|title=Chevrolet Increases Projected 2012 Volt Production Capacity by 50 Percent|work=[[Car and Driver]]|date=2010-07-30|accessdate=2010-08-03}} In May 2011, the carmaker again raised its production targets, as Volt and Ampera production capacity was increased to 16,000 units in 2011, including 3,500 units for exports and 2,500 demonstration units destined to U.S. dealerships, and the rest for U.S. sales. However, in November 2011 GM's sales chief announced that they would not meet its sales goal of 10,000 vehicles in 2011.{{cite news |last=Shepardson |first=David |title=GM Won't Meet 10,000 Volt Sales Goal in '11; CEO Vows To Buy Volts from Nervous Owners |url=http://detnews.com/article/20111201/AUTO01/112010446/1148/auto01/GM-won%E2%80%99t-meet-10-000-Volt-sales-goal-in-%E2%80%9911 |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=2011-12-01 |accessdate=2011-12-01 }}{{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}} Out of the 2012 production, General Motors expected to produce 10,000 Amperas for sale in Europe, 6,000 destined for Opel and 4,000 for Vauxhall in the UK. In addition, 2,000 Volts were available for the region.{{cite news |url=http://www.autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110804/ANE/110809903/1193|title=Opel/Vauxhall to receive 10,000 Amperas from GM next year |last=Jolley |first=David |work=[[Automotive News]]Europe |date=2011-08-04 |accessdate=2011-08-09}} By early 2012 GM abandoned its sales target to deliver 45,000 Volts in the U.S and instead announced that production in 2012 would depend on demand. By March 2012 the Volt plant has a global production capacity of 60,000 vehicles per year.{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/classified/automotive/sns-will-the-chevy-volt-be-sold-in-mexico-20120302,0,2764764.story |title=Will the Chevy Volt be sold in Mexico? |last=Popely |first=Rick |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=2012-03-02 |accessdate=2012-03-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306075055/http://www.chicagotribune.com/classified/automotive/sns-will-the-chevy-volt-be-sold-in-mexico-20120302,0,2764764.story |archive-date=2012-03-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The Volt's [[battery cell]]s are produced by [[LG Chem]] in [[South Korea]] and then shipped to the US, where the battery packs are assembled at a purpose-built facility in [[Brownstown Charter Township, Michigan]] owned and operated by General Motors.{{cite web|url=http://gm-volt.com/2009/01/12/its-official-gm-chooses-lg-chemcompact-power-inc-to-supply-chevy-volt-lithium-ion-battery-packs|title=GM Chooses LG Chem to Supply Chevy Volt’s Lithium-ion Batteries and Will Build the Packs Themselves|date=January 12, 2009|work=GM-Volt.com}} Compact Power, the North American subsidiary of LG Chem, is building a battery plant in [[Holland, Michigan]] to manufacture the advanced battery cells for the Volt and other carmakers, with capacity to produce enough cells for 50,000 to 200,000 battery packs per year.{{cite web|url=http://electriccarsreport.com/2011/03/lg-chem-wins-gm-supplier-of-the-year-award/|title=LG Chem Wins GM Supplier of the Year Award|work=Electric Cars Report|date=2011-03-17|accessdate=2011-05-19}} The {{USD|303}} million Holland plant was funded by 50% [[U.S. Department of Energy]] matching [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|stimulus funds]] and is planned to open by mid-2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/11/lgchem-20101107.html|title=LG Chem to establish new electrolyte production plant in Michigan|work=Green Car Congress|date=2010-11-07|accessdate=2011-05-19}} The 2011 Chevrolet Volt was officially launched on November 30, 2010 at a ceremony at the Hamtramck plant, where the first production unit for retail sale came off the assembly line. The first retail vehicle was delivered to a customer in [[Denville, New Jersey]] on December 15, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.plugincars.com/first-chevy-volts-reach-customers-will-out-deliver-nissan-december-106575.html|title=First Chevy Volts Reach Customers, Will Out-Deliver Nissan in December|work=plugincars.com|date=2010-12-16|accessdate=2010-12-17}} GM reported it had built 12,400 Volts in total through December 2011. This includes dealers' demo vehicles in North America and Amperas in dealerships in Europe, crash test vehicles and other unavailable Volts owned by GM. GM halted production for about one month at the Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly plant by mid June 2011 to complete some upgrades, including the installation of new tooling, equipment and overhead conveyor systems throughout the facility. These upgrades allowed GM to triple the rate of Volt production and prepared the plant for 2012 Volt and Ampera production.{{cite web |last=Shepardson |first=David |date=2011-07-19 |title=GM Restarts Volt Production |url=http://www.gminsidenews.com/forums/f13/gm-restarts-volt-production-output-now-3-times-initial-rate-only-100-dealers-104522/ |work=The Detroit News |accessdate=2011-05-31}} After the plant retooling, the production rate reached 150 units per day four days a week by August 2011.{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/08/31/volt-drawing-strangers-to-chevy-into-dealerships/|title=Volt drawing strangers to Chevy into dealerships |work=AutoblogGreen|date=2011-08-30|accessdate=2011-09-08}} The Volt plant was also down during January 2012 in preparation for building the California lower-emission version. A four-week shutdown due to slow sales took place between March and April 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-04-04/gm-ceo-seeks-to-boost-volt-s-monthly-sales-to-3-000.html|title=GM CEO Seeks to Boost Volt’s Monthly Sales to 3,000 |last=Higgins |first=Tim |work=[[Bloomberg Markets]]|date=2012-04-04|accessdate=2012-04-14}} GM said it had around 3,600 Volts in inventory and needed to reduce dealer inventories as production is expected to meet market demand.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/03/business/gm-suspends-production-of-chevrolet-volt.html?_r=1|title=G.M. Again Pauses Production of Chevy Volt|last=Bunkley |first=Nick|work=The New York Times|date=2012-03-02|accessdate=2012-03-07}}{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-autos-gm-volt-20120303,0,5159035.story|title=GM to pause Chevy Volt production for 5 weeks|last=Stevens |first=Matt|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2012-03-03|accessdate=2012-03-07}} GM also extended the traditional two-week summer vacation by an extra week at the Hamtramck plant.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/leisure/2012/04/03/chevy-volt-sales-double-in-march/|title=Chevy Volt sales double in March|work=[[Fox News]]|date=2012-04-03|accessdate=2012-04-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406024357/http://www.foxnews.com/leisure/2012/04/03/chevy-volt-sales-double-in-march/|archivedate=2012-04-06|df=}} GM closed its Detroit-Hamtramck plant from September 17 until October 15, 2012, affecting roughly 1,500 workers on downtime while the plant was retooled to assemble the all-new 2014 [[Chevrolet Impala]] alongside the 2013 Volt. This was the second time in 2012 that GM has halted Volt production.{{cite news|last=Healey|first=James|title=GM suspending Chevy Volt output, retooling for Impala|work=[[USA Today]]|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/driveon/post/2012/08/gm-suspends-chevy-volt-production-over-slow-sales/1#.UDywscGPUl8|date=2012-08-27|accessdate=2012-08-28}} Production of the 2013 model year Volt began in July 2012 and customer deliveries began during the same month.{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/news/2013-chevy-volts-now-available-48884.html|title=2013 Chevy Volts Now Available|last=Cobb |first=Jeff|work=HybridCars.com |date=2012-07-24|accessdate=2012-07-31}} In October 2012, GM announced they would build the [[Cadillac ELR]] extended-range luxury coupe at the Detroit-Hamtramck Assembly plant, together with the Chevrolet Volt, Opel Ampera, and Holden Volt. The addition of the ELR to the plant represents an additional {{USD|35}} million investment, bringing the total product investment to {{USD|561}} million since December 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/10/elr-20121016.html|title=Cadillac extended range electric vehicle ELR to be built at Detroit-Hamtramck |work=Green Car Congress |date=2012-10-16|accessdate=2012-10-17}} The first 2014 ELRs rolled off the production line in late May 2013. These were pre-production units destined for testing purposes before production for retail customers began at the end of 2013. Deliveries of the 2014 model year Volt began in August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/2014-chevrolet-volt-shipping-now/|title=2014 Chevrolet Volt Shipping Now|last=Cole |first=Jay|work=InsideEvs.com|date=2013-08-09|accessdate=2013-08-11}} Volt sales in the U.S. reached the 50,000 unit milestone in October 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/gm-sells-50000th-chevy-volt-in-october/|title=GM Sells 50,000th Chevy Volt In October|author=Jeff Cobb|publisher=HybridCars.com|date=2013-11-01|accessdate=2013-11-02}} out of more than 60,000 vehicles of the Volt/Ampera family sold worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/chevy-volt-sales-surpass-50000-in-us/|title=Chevy Volt Sales Surpass 50,000 in US|author=Eric Loveday|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2013-11-02|accessdate=2013-11-02}} Production of the 2015 model year Volt ended in mid-May 2015,{{cite web|url=http://www.topspeed.com/cars/car-news/last-first-gen-chevy-volt-rolls-off-the-assembly-line-ar169470.html#main|title=Last First-Gen Chevy Volt Rolls Off The Assembly Line|author= Jeffrey N. Ross|publisher=TopSpeed.com|date=2015-05-21|accessdate=2015-06-14}} while manufacturing of pre-production units of the second generation began in March 2015.{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/pre-production-2016-chevrolet-volts-now-built-pricing-announcement-expected-next-month/|title=Pre-Production 2016 Chevrolet Volts Now Being Built – Pricing Announcement Expected Next Month|author=Eric Loveday|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-03-31}} In July 2016, Volt sales in the American market passed the 100,000 unit milestone, out of about 117,000 Volt/Ampera family vehicles sold worldwide through June 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/top-selling-chevy-volt-crosses-100000-us-sales-milestone/ | title= Top-Selling Chevy Volt Crosses 100,000 US Sales Milestone |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com | date=2016-07-26 |accessdate= 2016-07-26}} ''{{As of|2016|06}}, around 117,000 units of the Volt/Ampera family have been sold globally, including close to 10,000 Opel/Vauxhall Ampera variants sold in Europe. Volt sales in the American market passed the 100,000 milestone in July 2016.''{{cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/100000th-chevy-volt-sold-in-us/ | title= 100,000th Chevy Volt Sold in US |first=Jeff |last=Cobb |work=HybridCars.com | date=2016-08-01 |accessdate= 2016-08-09}} In November 2018, GM announced it would cease Volt production in March 2019. ==== United States ==== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Chevrolet Volt WAS 2010 8852.JPG|image2=Chevrolet Volt WAS 2010 8846.JPG|width=220|caption1=2011 Volt's frontal view|caption2=2011 Rear view}} Sales of the 2011 Chevrolet Volt began in selected markets due to limited initial production, as General Motors' original target for 2011 was 10,000 units.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/07/01/autos/volt_release_states/index.htm?hpt=T2|title=Chevy Volt bound for Texas, New York area|work=[[CNN Money]]|last=Valdes-Dapena |first=Peter|date=2010-07-01|accessdate=2010-07-01}} The first cars were delivered in [[Washington D.C.]], the [[New York metropolitan area|New York City metropolitan region]], [[California]], and [[Austin, Texas]].{{cite news |last=Motavilli |first=Chris |date=2010-07-01 |title=Chevy Volt’s Initial Rollout to Include New York City |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/01/chevy-volts-initial-rollout-to-include-new-york-city/ |newspaper=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |at=Wheels |accessdate=2010-07-01}} By May 2011 the Volt had been launched also in [[Connecticut]], [[Maryland]], [[Michigan]], [[New Jersey]], and [[Virginia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/05/volt-20110519.html |title=Chevrolet Volt Plant Prepping for Boost in Volt and Ampera Production; Exports to Canada, China and Europe This Year |work=Green Car Congress |date=2011-05-19 |accessdate=2011-05-19}} Deliveries in [[Delaware]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Hawaii]], [[North Carolina]], [[Oregon]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[South Carolina]], and [[Washington (state)|Washington]] began in the third quarter of 2011. In June 2011, Chevrolet dealers nationwide began taking orders for the 2012 Volt, and deliveries in all 50 states began in November 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/06/volt-20110610.html|title=Chevrolet begins taking orders in all 50 US states for 2012 Volt; $1K drop in starting price|work=Green Car Congress|date=2011-06-10|accessdate=2011-06-10}}{{cite web |last=Loveday |first=Eric |title=2012 Chevrolet Volt Priced at $39,995*, Now Available To Order Ntionwide |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/06/10/2012-chevrolet-volt-priced-at-39-995-now-available-to-order-n/ |work=AutoblogGreen |publisher=AOL |date=2011-06-10 |accessdate=2011-06-10}} The [[suggested retail price]] (MSRP) for the 2011 Chevrolet Volt in the U.S. started at {{USD|40,280}}. That price excluded destination freight charge, tax, title, license, dealer fees, optional equipment—and savings due to factory incentives, tax deductions, or other subsidies for qualifying buyers.{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/07/chevrolet-volt-msrp-starts-at-41000-33500-net-of-full-federal-credit-3year-lease-program-with-option.html#more |title=Chevrolet Volt MSRP Starts at $41,000, $33,500 Net of Full Federal Credit; 3-year Lease Program with Option to Buy |work=Green Car Congress |date=2010-07-27 |accessdate=2010-07-27}}{{cite web |url=http://www.chevrolet.com/volt/|title=2011 Volt |publisher=General Motors Company |accessdate=2011-01-01}} The MSRP for the 2012 Volt starts at {{USD|39,995}} including a {{USD|850}} destination freight charge and excludes tax, title and license fees, or other available government subsidies. The base price is {{USD|1,005}} less than the 2011 [[model year]], and General Motors explained that this price reduction was possible because of a "wider range of options and configurations that come with the expansion of Volt production for sale nationally." The price dropped to {{USD|34,995}} including destination charges for the 2014 model year. Due to the capacity of the Volt's battery pack it qualifies for the maximum {{USD|7,500}} [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Federal government|federal tax credit]] as specified in the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008]].{{cite news |author= |title=Purchasers of Plug-In Cars Will Get Tax Credits |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27462414 |date=2008-10-30 |work=NBCnews.com |agency=Associated Press |quote= |accessdate=2009-07-25}} ''Plug-in electric cars with at least a 4-kilowatt-hour battery pack will be eligible for a {{USD|2,500}} credit, with an additional {{USD|417}} for each additional kilowatt-hour of battery capacity, up to {{USD|7,500}}. The Volt is eligible for the maximum credit.'' The federal tax credit phases out over a one-year period after the manufacturer has sold at least 200,000 vehicles in the U.S.{{cite web |author= |title=Notice 2009–89: New Qualified Plug-in Electric Drive Motor Vehicle Credit |url=https://www.irs.gov/irb/2009-48_IRB/ar09.html |publisher=[[Internal Revenue Service]] |date=2009-11-30 |accessdate=2010-04-01}} Several states also have additional [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Other states|incentives or rebates]] available for [[plug-in electric vehicle]]s for qualifying buyers.{{cite web|url=http://action.pluginamerica.org/t/5960/content.jsp?content_KEY=5545|title=State and Federal Incentives for EVs, PHEVs and Charge Stations|publisher=[[Plug In America]]|accessdate=2010-05-29}} The 2011 Volt price including all available regular production and premium options is {{USD|44,600}}, including destination charges and before tax credits or any subsidies.{{cite news |last=Motavalli |first=Jim |date=2010-07-28 |title=The $41,000 Question: Is the Chevy Volt Worth the Money? |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/28/the-41000-question-is-the-chevy-volt-worth-the-money/?hpw |newspaper=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |at=Wheels |accessdate=2010-07-31}} For the 2012 model year the price of the Volt with all available options is {{USD|46,265}} before tax credits or any subsidies available. {{As of|2018|10}}, General Motors combined sales of plug-in electric vehicles in the U.S. totaled almost 197,000 units and are expected to pass 200,000 early in 2019. Thereafter, the applicable tax credit reduces gradually until it is completely phased out beginning on January 1, 2020.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/arielcohen/2018/11/30/gm-must-adapt-or-die-a-lesson-for-u-s-automakers/ |title=GM Must Adapt Or Die: A Lesson For U.S. Automakers |first=Ariel |last=Cohen |work=Forbes |date=2018-11-30| accessdate=2018-12-01}} [[File:Barack Obama driving at the White House.jpg|thumb|left|[[President Obama]] driving a Volt at the [[White House]].]] The price for the home [[charging station|charging units]] is {{USD|490}} plus installation costs. The [[Voltec]] is a home-charging unit built by [[SPX Corporation|SPX]] for Volt owners. It is a 240-volt ([[Level 1, 2, and 3 charging#US Charging Standards|Level II]]) charger, and, according to General Motors, can replenish the Volt's batteries in about four hours. Consumer Reports has advised buyers to budget up to {{USD|2,000}}, as many older homes may need a substantial electrical upgrade because the U.S. [[National Electrical Code]] requires that the charger have its own dedicated 220-volt, 30-amp circuit.{{cite web|url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/news/2010/10/pricing-chevrolet-volt-home-charger-to-cost-490-to-2-000/index.htm|title=Pricing: Chevrolet Volt home charger to cost $490 to $2,000|work=Consumer Reports|last=Evarts |first=Eric|date=2010-10-06|accessdate=2014-01-06}} Early buyers can benefit from the [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Charging Equipment|federal tax credit]] available for charging equipment.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/10/gm-prices-volt-home-charger-installation-names-national-installer.html|title=GM Prices Volt Home Charger, Installation; Names National Installer|work=Edmunds.com|date=2010-10-07|accessdate=2010-10-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010023313/http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/10/gm-prices-volt-home-charger-installation-names-national-installer.html|archivedate=2010-10-10|df=}} The 2011 Volt was not submitted for application to the [[California Air Resources Board]]'s (CARB) [[Clean Vehicle Rebate Project]] rebate and therefore was not required to meet the 10-year {{convert|150,000|mi|km|adj=on}} battery warranty requirement for [[partial zero-emissions vehicle|enhanced advanced technology partial zero-emissions vehicle]]s (enhAT-PZEV). The Volt team explained that for the launch General Motors decided to go with a common national package that includes an 8-year {{convert|100,000|mi|km|adj=on}} battery warranty.{{cite web|url=https://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project/frequently-asked-questions-cvrp#general|title=Clean Vehicle Rebate Project General CVRP Questions: Why does the Chevrolet Volt NOT qualify this year?|publisher=Center for Sustainable Energy California|accessdate=2011-05-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015173641/http://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project/frequently-asked-questions-cvrp#general|archivedate=2011-10-15|df=}} For this reason owners of the 2011 Volt did not qualify for [[Clean Vehicle Rebate Project|California's rebate]]s and free access to use [[carpool lane]]s even when traveling solo.{{cite news |last=Motavalli |first=Jim |date=2011-09-20 |title=Banished from the H.O.V. Lane, Prius Drivers May Be First to Embrace New Plug-In Model |url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/20/banished-from-the-h-o-v-lane-prius-drivers-may-be-first-to-embrace-new-plug-in-model/ |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |at=Wheels |accessdate=2011-09-25}} A third package, scheduled for 2013, is under development with an [[E85]] [[flexible fuel vehicle|flex-fuel engine]]. General Motors engineering team commented that "introducing two or three packages of an entirely new technology set and platform at the same time wasn't an option." [[File:1st gen Volt at Naval Air Station Alameda CA.jpg|thumb|Chevrolet Volt with California's [[HOV lane]] access green sticker.]] In February 2012 General Motors began deliveries of a low emission version destined for California that features a new low emissions package that allows the 2012 Chevrolet Volt to qualify as an enhanced, advanced technology –partial zero emissions vehicle (enhAT-PZEV) and have access to California’s [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]]s (HOV).{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2012/02/24/gm-starts-deliveries-of-2012-hov-lane-eligible-chevy-volts-in-ca/|title=GM starts deliveries of 2012 HOV-lane-eligible Chevy Volts in California |last=King |first=Danny |work=AutoblogGreen |date=2012-02-24|accessdate=2012-02-27}} The new standard California version of the Volt features a modified engine and exhaust components. The [[catalytic converter]] was modified to add a secondary air-injection pump that "''streams ambient air into the exhaust stream to increase its ability to remove pollutants''." Owners of a 2012 Volt with the low emissions package are eligible to apply for one of 40,000 available HOV lane stickers issued to vehicles that qualify as a California AT-PZEV. The permits are handed out on a first-apply, first-served basis. Additionally, the new low emissions package makes the 2012 Volt eligible for owners to receive up to {{USD|1,500}} in state rebates through the state’s Clean Vehicle Rebate Project (CVRP). This incentive is in addition to the federal government’s {{USD|7,500}} tax credit.{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/11/16/new-enhat-pzev-chevy-volt-ready-for-california-hov-access-extra/#continued|title=2012 Volt Moves Into California's HOV Fast Lane|work=AutoblogGreen |date=2011-11-16|accessdate=2011-11-17}} ''See details in GM Press Release''.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/11/volt-20111117.html|title=Chevy Volt gets a Low Emissions Package for California; HOV lanes access|work=Green Car Congress|date=2011-11-17|accessdate=2011-11-17}} Only the 2012 Volts manufactured after February 6, 2012, are fitted with the low emission package and sold as standard models in California.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1071925_can-your-2012-chevy-volt-use-california-hov-lanes-it-depends|title=Can Your 2012 Chevy Volt Use California HOV Lanes? It Depends|author=Nikki Gordon-Bloomfield|work=Green Car Reports|date=2012-01-19|accessdate=2012-01-20}} Other states where the Volt has solo driving access to HOV lanes are Florida, Georgia, New York and Virginia.{{cite web|url=http://www.dmv.virginia.gov/vehicles/#cleanspecialfuel.asp|title=Clean Special Fuel Vehicles/Plates|work=Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles|accessdate=2013-04-02}} ;U.S. sales Since sales began in December 2010, a total of 148,556 Volts have been sold in the country through October 2018.{{cite web|url=https://insideevs.com/chevrolet-volt-dead-electric-car-sales-leader/ |title=RIP Chevy Volt: USA’s Best-Selling Electric Car Of All Time | first=Mark | last=Kane | publisher=InsideEVs.com| date=2018-11-29 | accessdate=2018-12-01}} December 2016 is the best monthly sales volume on record ever, with 3,691 units delivered. Sales in 2016 set a calendar year record of 24,739 sales. The previous annual record was 2012 with 23,461 units sold.{{ cite news | url=http://www.hybridcars.com/chevy-bolt-sales-begin-volt-smashes-sales-records/ |title= Chevy Bolt Sales Begin; Volt Smashes Sales Records | first= Jeff | last=Cobb | work= HybridCars.com | date=2017-01-04 |accessdate=2017-01-05}} The Volt ranked as the all-time top selling [[plug-in electric car]] in the United States until February 2015, when it was surpassed by the all-electric [[Nissan Leaf]] in March 2015.{{cite web|url=http://insideevs.com/nissan-leaf-sales-strengthen-in-march-takes-overall-us-plug-in-sales-lead/|title=Nissan LEAF Sales Strengthen In March, Takes All-Time US Plug-In Sales Lead |author=Jay Cole|publisher=InsideEVs.com|date=2015-04-01|accessdate=2015-04-02}} Cumulative Volt sales passed Leaf sales in March 2016, and became once again the best selling plug-in car in the U.S. ever.{{cite news| url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/04/04/chevy-volt-reclaims-us-plug-in-sales-crown-from-nissan-leaf/ | title=Chevy Volt reclaims US plug-in sales crown from Nissan Leaf |first=Sebastian |last=Blanco | work=Autoblog.com | date=2016-04-04 | accessdate=2016-04-06}} ''{{As of|2016|03}}, the Chevrolet Volt is the all-time selling plug-in car in the U.S. with 92,737 units, while the Nissan Leaf ranks second with 92,522 units sold, both, since December 2010.'' In July 2016, Volt sales in the American market passed the 100,000 unit milestone. {{asof|2018|10}}, the Volt continued to rank as the all-time [[plug-in electric car]] in the U.S. ;Resale value [[File:Chevy Volt EDTA DC 04 2011 1787.jpg|thumb|left|Production Volts at a test drive event in [[Washington, D.C.]]]] In May 2011 [[Kelley Blue Book]] (KBB) projected the 2011 Chevrolet Volt resale value at just over {{USD|17,000}} after 36 months, the length of a typical lease, which represents 42% of the car's {{USD|41,000}} [[suggested retail price]] (MSRP). KBB explains that even though the residual value seems low, the projection considered that the first 200,000 Volts sold qualified for a {{USD|7,500}} federal tax credit, which effectively reduces the MSRP to {{USD|33,500}}, making the {{USD|17,000}}represent 51% of its original value after the tax credit. In comparison, KBB notes, the 2011 Toyota Prius has a projected residual of 46% after 36 months. KBB's estimate assumed a gasoline price around {{USD|4}} per gallon in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/05/17/kbb-sets-chevy-volt-resale-value-at-17-000-after-36-months/ |title=KBB sets Chevy Volt resale value at $17,000 after 36 months |author=Automotive News|work=AutoblogGreen|date=2011-05-17|accessdate=2011-05-21}} For 2012, Kelley Blue Book expected the Volt to retain 42% of its original value after 3 years and 27% after 5 years. Based on these figures, in November 2011 KBB awarded the Volt with the 2012 Best Resale Value Awards in the [[plug-in electric car]] category. KBB explains that the residual value for the Volt is lower than the market 35.5% average due to the {{USD|7,500}} federal tax credit, which lowers the transaction price and pushes down the residual value.{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/16/toyota-and-lexus-are-back-on-top-in-kelley-blue-book-resale-value-survey/?ref=automobiles|title=Toyota and Lexus Are Back on Top in Kelley Blue Book Resale Value Survey|author=Cheryl Jensen|work=The New York Times|date=2011-11-16|accessdate=2011-11-17}} [[Consumer Reports]]' analysis show that many Chevrolets lose about half of their purchase price after three years of ownership, and if the Volt depreciates the same, {{USD|17,000}} seems a reasonable estimate. However, Consumer Reports have noted that fuel-efficient hybrids and diesel models often depreciate far less than most vehicles, which might increase the Volt's resale value after three years above the {{USD|17,000}} estimate. Additionally, if gasoline prices continue to rise or if the tax credits expire, the demand for used Chevrolet Volts could quickly increase, raising their market value. On the other hand, if the next-generation Volt’s battery has twice the capacity and cost less, as General Motors has claimed, the first generation Volts would be obsolete when the new ones come out in 2015. Considering these assumptions, Consumer Reports said, "At this point we believe it’s still unclear how the Volt will fare."{{cite web|url=http://news.consumerreports.org/cars/2011/05/cheverolet-volts-resale-value-after-three-years-17000.html|title=Chevrolet Volt resale value after three years? $17,000|work=Consumer Reports|date=2011-05-18|accessdate=2011-05-21}} ;Pecan Street demonstration project General Motors is sponsoring the [[Pecan Street demonstration project]] at the Mueller neighborhood in [[Austin, Texas]]. The project objective is to learn the charging patterns of plug-in electric car owners, and to study how a residential fleet of electric vehicles might strain the electric grid if all owners try to charge them at the same, which is what the preliminary monitoring found when the plug-in cars return home in the evening. {{As of|2013|06}}, the community has nearly 60 Chevrolet Volt owners alone thanks to GM's commitment to match the federal government's {{USD|7,500}} rebate incentive, which halves the purchase price of the Volt.{{cite news|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=remote-control-of-electric-cars|title=Will You or the Grid Control Your Electric Car?|author=David Biello|work=[[Scientific America]]|date=2013-06-18|accessdate=2013-06-23}} ==== Canada ==== [[File:Chevrolet Volt MIA 09 2017 5621.jpg|thumb|The second generation Volt is only sold in the U.S. and Canada.]] Chevrolet began taking orders in May 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/05/volt-20110504.html#tp|title=Chevrolet Canada begins taking orders for the Volt starting at C$41,545; Volts a showroom draw in US|work=Green Car Congress|date=2011-05-04|accessdate=2011-05-05}}{{cite web|url=http://media.gm.ca/content/media/ca/en/news/news_detail.brand_gm.html/content/Pages/news/ca/en/2010/Dec/1202_Volt_Markets|title=Chevrolet Volt Canadian Launch Markets Revealed|work=General Motors Media|date=2010-12-02|accessdate=2010-12-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20101208040852/http://media.gm.ca/content/media/ca/en/news/news_detail.brand_gm.html/content/Pages/news/ca/en/2010/Dec/1202_Volt_Markets|archivedate=2010-12-08|df=}} and deliveries began in September 2011 in major cities only.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/story/2011/09/01/chevy-volt-canada.html|title=Chevy brings electric Volt to Canada|author=The Canadian Press|work=[[CBC News]]|date=2011-09-01|accessdate=2011-09-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bclocalnews.com/greater_vancouver/burnabynewsleader/news/130147388.html|title=Eager customer takes delivery of Chevy Volt in Burnaby|author=Wanda Chow|work=Burnaby NewsLeader News|date=2011-09-19|accessdate=2011-09-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110923192725/http://www.bclocalnews.com/greater_vancouver/burnabynewsleader/news/130147388.html|archivedate=2011-09-23|df=}} During 2012 the Volt was the best selling plug-in car in Canada, outselling all other PEVs combined.{{cite web |url=http://www.hybridcars.com/chevy-volt-price-reduction-confirmed-for-canada-also-5000/ |title=Chevy Volt Price Reduction Confirmed For Canada; Also $5,000 |last=Crowe |first=Phillipe |website=HybridCars.com |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2013-08-14}} Despite a 24% reduction from 2012 sales, the Volt continued as the top selling PEV in the Canadian market in 2013, and again in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1089601_plug-in-electric-car-sales-in-canada-in-2013-up-50-percent|title=Plug-In Electric Car Sales In Canada In 2013: Up 50 Percent|author=Matthew Klippenstein|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2014-01-15|accessdate=2014-01-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1096205_plug-in-electric-car-sales-for-canada-in-2014-steady-growth|title=Plug-In Electric Car Sales For Canada In 2014: Steady Growth|author=Matthew Klippenstein|publisher=Green Car Reports|date=2015-01-15|accessdate=2015-06-14}} {{As of|2018|09}}, the Volt continued to rank as the all-time top selling plug-in electric car in Canada. Since September 2011, a total of 16,653 new Volts have been delivered in Canada through the end of October 2018. The monthly sales record was set in May 2018 with 731 deliveries.{{cite web| url=http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2011/01/chevrolet-volt-sales-figures.html| title=Chevrolet Volt Sales Figures| first=Timothy |last=Cain| work=Good Car Bad Car| date=October 2018 |accessdate=2018-12-01}} Sales in 2016 set a calendar year record of 3,469 units delivered. The suggested retail price (MSRP) for the 2012 Chevrolet Volt started at {{CAD|41,545}} ({{USD|42,423}} in June 2011). This excludes any charges, fees, and optional equipment—and is before any available subsidies or incentives for qualifying buyers. The Canadian market offers the Volt in one standard trim level with two option packages: ''Premium Trim Package'' and ''Rear Camera and Park Assist Package''. Some provinces are offering [[Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles#Canada|Government incentives]] including Ontario,{{cite news|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/story_print.html?id=3843542&sponsor=|title=We'll go green if the price is right|author=Garry Marr|work=Ottawa Citizen|date=2010-11-17|accessdate=2011-06-02}}{{cite rebates of up to C$8,000|author=Eric Loveday|work=AutoblogGreen|date=2011-04-11|accessdate=2011-06-08}} (both at {{CAD|8,500}} {{USD|8,680}}) and British Columbia has announced their new ''LiveSmart Europe === The European version of the Volt, the [[Opel]] Ampera (known as the [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]] Ampera in the United Kingdom),{{cite news|url=http://www.carmagazine.co.uk/News/Search-Results/Industry-News/Chevrolet-Volt-for-UK-sale-in-November-2011/|title=Chevrolet Volt for European sale in November 2011|author=Tim Pollard|work=[[Car Magazine]] Online|date=2010-12-13|accessdate=2010-05-20}} was unveiled at the [[Geneva Auto Show]] in March 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.motorauthority.com/blog/1032003_european-volt-makes-official-debut-as-the-new-opel-ampera|title=European Volt makes official debut as the new Opel Ampera|work=Motor Authority |date=2009-03-02|accessdate=2010-07-02}} and also was exhibited at the 2009 [[Frankfurt Auto Show]].{{cite web|url=http://www.calcars.org/calcars-news/1072.html |title=The Ultimate Posting on Plug-In Hybrid Developments: Clip & Save|work=Calcars.org|accessdate=2009-10-13}} Opel developed the battery control modules for the Ampera at the Opel Alternative Propulsion Center Europe in Mainz-Kastel, [[Germany]].{{cite web |url=http://www.autostrassenverkehr.de/aktuell/zukunft/hxcms_article_503129_14972.hbs |title=AUTOStraßenverkehr |work=Autostrassenverkehr.de |date= |accessdate=2009-08-19 version of the Ampera was unveiled at the 2011 [[Geneva Motor Show]]. The Ampera is assembled at the Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly plant, Michigan. {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=left|image1=Opel Ampera.JPG|image2=Opel Ampera Heck.JPG|width=220|caption1=Opel Ampera frontal view|caption2=Opel Ampera rear view}} The main differences between the Volt and the Ampera are in their styling. The Ampera has a distinctive front and rear [[Fascia (car)|fascia]], with a large cut-out in the rear [[Bumper (automobile)|bumper]]. The Opel Ampera features more stylized alloy wheels as standard, and the side skirts are body-colored rather than black. In the inside there are only minor differences and both versions share the same exact powertrain and battery pack.{{cite web|url=http://www.allcarselectric.com/blog/1056301_chevrolet-volt-and-opel-ampera-what-are-the-differences |title=Chevrolet Volt and Opel Ampera: What Are The Differences? |author=Antony Ingram |work=AllCarsElectric.com |date=2011-03-04 |accessdate=2011-05-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.greenmotor.co.uk/2011/04/enno-fuchs-ampera-volt-uk-europe.html|title=Is the Ampera any more than a Volt with a nose job?|work=GreenMotor.co.uk|date=2011-04-17|accessdate=2011-05-21}} A key operational difference was that the Ampera has four drive modes, one more than the 2011/12 model year Volt. The additional option is ''City Mode'', which adapts battery management to the needs of [[commuting|commuter travel]]. City mode or "battery hold" engages the range-extender immediately, allowing to save the energy currently stored in the battery, and when switched off, the range-extender stops and the Ampera is then able to use the energy saved in the battery for pure electric driving, for example for traveling urban areas or restricted zones, such as the European [[low emission zone]]s or to allow the Ampera to qualify for an exemption of the [[London congestion charge]]{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/05/20/bibendum-2011-opel-ampera-not-only-looks-better-than-the-chevy/|title=Bibendum 2011: Opel Ampera not only looks better than the Chevy Volt, it can do more, too|author=Sebastian Blanco|work=AutoblogGreen|date=2011-05-20|accessdate=2011-05-21}} The 2013 model year Volt included the "Hold Drive" button to allow drivers to conserve battery-pack energy for use at a particular time of their choice. ;Sales General Motors production target for 2012 was to manufacture 10,000 Amperas for sale in Europe, 6,000 destined for Opel and 4,000 for Vauxhall in the UK, plus an additional 2,000 Volts were to be made available for the region. The carmaker targeted the Ampera for business fleet market and local government agencies, where Opel has a strong customer base, while the Volt is aimed at retail customers. According to Opel, by June 2011 around 5,000 customers across Europe had reserved an Ampera, with fleet or business customers representing 60% of reservations,{{cite |date=2011-07-08|accessdate=2011-07-10}} ''See Opel press release''. and a total of 7,000 orders were received by March 2012, with [[Benelux]], Germany and the United Kingdom as the top markets in offered through Zipcar car sharing scheme|work=Green Car Congress|date=2012-05-20|accessdate=2012-05-21}} [[File:2014 Vauxhall Ampera Positiv CVT 1.4 Front.jpg|thumb|Amperas destined for the UK market carry the [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]] badge.]] The Opel/Vauxhall Ampera was Europe's top selling plug-in electric car in 2012 with 5,268 units and captured a 21.5% market share of the region's plug-in electric passenger car segment. {{As of|2013|10}}, the Ampera held a market share of almost 10% of European registration of plug-in electric cars since 2011. The market share in the Netherlands was 40% and 10% in Germany.{{cite web|url=http://www.ev-sales.blogspot.ca/2013/11/europe-october-2013.html|title=Europe October 2013|author=Jose Pontes|publisher=EV Sales|date=2013-11-23|accessdate=2013-11-23}} Ampera sales fell 40% in 2013 to 3,184 cars,{{cite news|url=http://europe.autonews.com/article/20140721/ANE/307259991/opel-will-discontinue-weak-selling-ampera-sources-say|title=Opel will discontinue weak-selling Ampera, sources say|author=Mike Colias|work=[[Automotive News|Automotive News Europe]]|date=2014-07-21|accessdate=2014-07-23}} ''Ampera sales in Europe totaled 3,184 units in 2013''. and within the plug-in hybrid segment, the Ampera was surpassed in 2013 by the [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] (8,197), [[Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid|Volvo V60 plug-in]] (7,437), and the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid|Prius plug-in]] (4,314). In 2013 the Ampera ranked eighth among Europe's top selling plug-in electric vehicles, and its market share fell to about 5%.{{cite news|url=http://www.automotiveworld.com/news-releases/mitsubishi-outlander-phev-cy13-sales-european-inauguration/|title=Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV CY13 sales – European inauguration|author=Mitsubishi News Release|work=[[Automotive News]]|date=2014-01-20|accessdate=2014-07-24}} ''A total of 8,197 Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEVs were sold in Europe in 2013''.{{cite web|url=http://ev-sales.blogspot.com.br/2014/01/europe-december-2013.html|title=Europe December 2013|author=EV Sales|date=2014-01-26|accessdate=2014-07-24}} ''A total of 7,437 Volvo V60 PHEVs and 4,314 Prius PHEVs were sold in Europe in 2013''. During the first five months of 2014, only 332 units had been sold, down 67% from the same period in 2013. In July 2014, Opel announced that due to the slowdown in sales, they would discontinue the Ampera after the second generation Volt launch—and that between 2014 and 2018, they plan to introduce a successor electric vehicle in Europe.{{cite news|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20140723/OEM04/140729943/opel-plans-electric-successor-to-ampera-plug-in-hybrid|title=Opel plans 'electric' successor to Ampera plug-in hybrid|author=Staff|work=[[Automotive News]]|date=2014-07-23|accessdate=2014-07-23}} Ampera sales totaled 939 units in 2014, and only 215 units during the first nine months of 2015. {{As of|2016|06}}, Opel/Vauxhall Ampera sales totaled just over 10,000 units since 2011,{{cite news | url=http://www.autohaus.de/nachrichten/ampera-e-opel-bringt-2017-neues-elektroauto-1754252.html | title= Opel bringt 2017 neues Elektroauto |language=German|trans-title= Opel brings new electric car in 2017 |author=Staff | work=Autohaus.de | date=2016-02-11| accessdate=2016-03-31}} ''About 10,000 Opel Amperas were sold in Europe by the end of 2015.'' with the Netherlands as the leading market with 5,031 Amperas registered, followed by Germany with 1,542 units, and the UK with 1,250 units registered by the end of June 2015. The Netherlands is also the top selling Volt market in Europe with 1,062 units registered through December 2014, out of about 1,750 Volts sold through 2014. ;Pricing In February 2011 Opel announced they would offer the Ampera throughout the [[Eurozone]] for a uniform {{€|42,900}} ({{USD|56,920}}, including [[VAT]].
